questions.question: Is the seahorse made entirely of glass material instead of plush fabric?
questions.explanation: In Image B, the surface of the seahorse has a shiny, reflective quality, indicating it is made from glass or a similar material rather than plush fabric, which is typically soft and non-reflective. Visual cues like smoothness and reflective highlights support this analysis.

questions.question: Does the body of the seahorse have a translucent pink glass appearance with visible subtle bubble textures?
questions.explanation: Image B shows the seahorse with a glossy, translucent pink appearance suggesting it is made from glass. However, there are no noticeable bubble textures visible on the body, as the surface appears smooth and uniformly colored.

questions.question: Is the belly section made of opaque yellow glass with an etched music note design?
questions.explanation: The belly section of the seahorse in Image B is yellow and appears opaque like glass. It has a music note design visible, resembling etching that you might see on glass. The reflective property and design style suggest it is made from glass material.

questions.question: Are the ribbons on the head and fins made of lavender-colored glass instead of fabric?
questions.explanation: The ribbons on the head and fins in Image B appear to have a glass-like, shiny texture with lavender color, contrasting with the more matte appearance of fabric ribbons. The reflection and the structure suggest a glass material.

questions.question: Is the seahorse placed on a reflective black display stand?
questions.explanation: Image B clearly shows the seahorse mounted on a black stand that reflects light, indicating it is a display stand possibly made from a material like polished wood or plastic that has a high-gloss finish.
